title: Schedule of Ratings - Neurological Conditions and Convulsive Disorders
description: Rating criteria for peripheral nerve conditions, headaches, and seizures

complete_vs_incomplete.complete_paralysis: Total loss of function of the nerve

incomplete_paralysis.moderate: Noticeable motor weakness and sensory disturbance
incomplete_paralysis.severe: Marked motor weakness or sensory disturbance, may have muscle atrophy

major_vs_minor.description: Upper extremity nerve ratings differ based on dominance
major_vs_minor.major: Dominant arm (usually right for right-handed people)

levels.criteria: Characteristic prostrating attacks averaging one in 2 months over the last several months
Characteristic prostrating attacks occurring on an average once a month over the last several months
Very frequent completely prostrating and prolonged attacks productive of severe economic inadaptability

definitions.prostrating: Causing extreme exhaustion, powerlessness, debilitation, or incapacitation with substantial inability to engage in ordinary activities
definitions.severe_economic_inadaptability: Significantly impacts ability to work and earn income (does not require unemployment)

8510.name: Upper radicular group (fifth and sixth cervicals)

complete.description: All shoulder and elbow movements lost or severely affected; hand and wrist movements not affected
Drop of hand and fingers, wrist and fingers perpetually flexed
Hand inclined to ulnar side; index and middle fingers cannot make fist; cannot flex distal phalanx of thumb; atrophy of thenar muscles
Griffin claw deformity; cannot spread fingers; cannot adduct thumb; atrophy of interossei

8520.name: Sciatic nerve

complete.description: Foot dangles and drops, no active movement possible below the knee, flexion of knee weakened or lost

8520.note: Most commonly claimed lower extremity nerve condition

complete.description: Foot drop and slight droop of first phalanges of all toes; cannot dorsiflex foot; extension of proximal phalanges lost
Plantar flexion lost, cannot flex toes or move foot inward; atrophy of plantar muscles

levels.criteria: A confirmed diagnosis with a history of seizures
At least 1 major seizure in the last 2 years; or at least 2 minor seizures in the last 6 months
At least 1 major seizure in the last 6 months or 2 in the last year; or averaging at least 5-8 minor seizures weekly
Averaging at least 1 major seizure in 4 months over the last year; or 9-10 minor seizures per week
Averaging at least 1 major seizure in 3 months over the last year; or more than 10 minor seizures weekly
Averaging at least 1 major seizure per month over the last year

important_rules: Upper extremity ratings differ based on dominant (major) vs non-dominant (minor) arm
Radiculopathy should always be claimed separately from spine conditions
Each affected nerve can be rated separately
Both sides (bilateral) can be rated separately
Prostrating for headaches means unable to perform ordinary activities
50% headache rating requires both frequent attacks AND economic impact

radiculopathy_claim_tip.message: If you have a spine condition (neck or back), ALWAYS claim radiculopathy as a secondary condition. Radiculopathy is rated separately from the spine condition itself and can significantly increase overall disability rating.
